body: Sorry about this, that warning is indeed erroneous.  It should not warn for the block within a block, as like you say, it could be used.  This will be fixed in the next version of jade.
I have the same issue in 1.5 version. Source code of warn message is in the lib/parser.js file. The temporary solution for me is to comment this line of code. I hope you will fix it soon. Thanks.

@Dissimulazione Can you provide example code that produces the warnings please?  That way I can figure out if they are genuine errors.  If they are not, I will then fix whatever bug causes them to be reported as warnings.

Without knowing what code is producing the error, it won't get fixed.  I believe I have fixed all the cases that people have presented in the issue tracker.

There is a simple example with my real project's structure: http://puu.sh/aqgxG/a80b77fcbf.zip.
Jade usage:

```
jade -o public -O options.json -P develop\jade\views
```

I have 4 warnings about unexpected blocks, though jade usage and html output are correct, I suppose.
@ForbesLindesay, thanks a lot, it's fixed now.

I've got a base layout like that. 

``` jade
doctype html
html
    block variables        
    head
        title= title
        link(rel='stylesheet', href='//maxcdn.bootstrapcdn.com/bootstrap/3.3.6/css/bootstrap.min.css')
        link(rel='stylesheet', href='/css/app.css')
    body
        header
        section.container
            include ./partials/topNavigation
            block content
```

I use `block variables` to declare some common data which is gonna be shared between blocks. I may or may not use this inside my blocks. I get the warning mentioned above though. Is this the good way to share data like that? If yes, the warning probably has no sense then.

You should only get the warning for the template that makes the `extend` call, not for the layout template.  Can you check you haven't mis-spelt `variables` in one of your child templates, and if that's the case, provide the pair of templates that produce this warning and we can see if it reproduces?
Indeed, it was a typo. Sorry for bothering.

issue.title: Added Jade Template

repository.name: DevTips-Starter-Kit
repository.description: Ground zero for your next project.

issue.body:
Based on DevTips Starter Kit V2.

Added simple jade template // Jade allows you to create sophisticated
patterns of template inheritance through includes or the extends and
block keywords.

If using CodeKit you may get Warning: Unexpected block. I understand
this is an old bug with jade when using extends.
It does however render out perfectly. Just a little annoying.
https://github.com/pugjs/pug/issues/1593

body: +1  that this is *still* happening as of January 5, 2016, with Jade v1.11.0 (installed with npm v4.0.5, node.js v6.9.3 (latest LTS) and Express.JS v4.14.0 on a MacOS Sierra v10.12.2).

Still happening.
Example code:
```
extends layouts/default

block content
  section.blog-page.spacing
    .container
      .row
        .col-xs-12
          h2.heading-title.nm Blog
          .cat-filter
            .row.oe-row-sm-gap
              .col-xs-9.col-sm-4.col-sm-offset-3.col-md-3.col-md-offset-4.oe-col
                label.select-faker.select-bordered.select-fw
                  select(name="abc")
                    option Tt c cc chuyn mc
                    option(value="1") Gi vng
                    option(value="2") Cat name 2
                  span
                    i.icon-arrow-down
              .col-xs-3.col-sm-2.col-md-1.oe-col
                button.btn-bordered.btn.btn-md OK
          .blog-list
            .row
              - for (var i = 0; i < 9; i++)
                .col-sm-6
                  article.blog-wrapper
                    .blog-thumb
                      a.thumb.rec-fill.full-cover(href="#", style="background-image: url(" + demoDir + "thumbnail1.jpg)")
                        img.img-semantic(src= demoDir + "thumbnail1.jpg", alt="Blog title")
                    h1.blog-heading.heading-md.under-sep
                      a(href="#") Lorem Ipsum is simply dummy text of the printing
                    .blog-desc
                      p Lorem Ipsum is simply dummy text of the printing and type industry. Lorem Ipsum has been the industry's standard dummy text since the 1500s, when an unknown printer took a galley of type...
                        a.readmore(href="#") Read More
                - if (i%2 == 1)
                  .clearfix.hidden-xs
```

If it's still happening with the latest version of pug, please open a new issue.  However, make sure you:

1. Include all code needed to reproduce the error (e.g. @ptaking you haven't included the template you're extending, so I have no idea whether you've really found a bug)
2. Remove irrelevant code.  I really doubt all those divs with class names are causing this bug.

If you don't do that, I will just close your issue.  I'm going to lock this issue as further comments saying "me too" without proper steps to reproduce are not helpful and drain time that could be spent fixing bugs.
